root.text:
Volvo S60 in ways is mini-S80 model.

Think of the S60 as a scaled-down version of Volvo's flagship S80 model. Not exactly a Mini-Me of the S80 (the S80 is 10 inches longer, 1 inch wider and 1 inch taller than the S60), the S60 shares a modified version of its platform and many of its mechanicals.

The manufacturer's suggested retail price of the entry-level S60 is about $10,000 less than that of the S80, too. In other words, if you like the S80, you probably will feel the same about its smaller sibling.

A new model, the S60 replaces the squarish and dated S70 in Volvo's lineup. This Swedish manufacturer has a showroom stuffed with svelte sedans, coupes, wagons and convertibles. The new S60 looks right at home among Volvo's more stylized entries. The sloping roof line of the S60, a sedan, almost gives it the appearance of a coupe. Its well-defined belt line begins at the front of the hood and continues unhindered to the tip of the trunk lid. This is a beautiful design, shocking many a passer-by into asking if it really is a Volvo. It has nary a right angle or straight line anywhere on it.

Volvo traditionally has claimed the safety high ground. Its current crop of vehicles doesn't deviate from its safety heritage; however, performance now is as important an element of a Volvo's equation as safety.

Three five-cylinder engines with varying degrees of vigor power the S60. A normally aspirated 2.4-liter is good for 168 horsepower, while a light turbocharged version of the 2.4 bumps up the heat to 197 horsepower. The most powerful of the trio is a 247-horsepower 2.3-liter turbocharged engine. The 2.4 and 2.3 T can be fitted with either a five-speed manual or a five-speed automatic. The 2.4T is available with only the five-speed automatic.

The test Volvo was the high-performance S60 T5. This is Volvo-speak for the 2.3T engine. The five-speed manual transmission passed my 2.3T's output to the front wheels.

If you think the S60's exterior styling is a departure from Volvos of old, wait until you get a load of its performance. Putting a foot on the accelerator is rewarded with an immediate burst of energy. The turbo spools up instantly. Going from zero to 60 mph can take less than seven seconds.

The shifter works smoothly, adding to the fun. Fuel economy is decent, too, with an Environmental Protection Agency rating of 21 mpg in town and 28 mpg on the highway.

Handling is crisp and predictable. Sticky 17-inch tires nearly lock the S60 to the pavement. It goes where it is pointed. The steering offers just the right amount of resistance. Although the ride differs among the three models from the softer experience of the entry-level version to the performance-tuned architecture of the T5, passenger comfort is not a trade-off for sharp handling. The fully independent suspension absorbs imperfections in the pavement without disturbing the passenger compartment, yet the S60 retains its composure when flung into a turn.

Loaded with safety features, the S60 won't disappoint the "Baby on Board" set. Front side-impact air bags are supplemented by Volvo's Inflatable Curtain Side Impact Head Protection System. A Whiplash Protection System is built into the front seats to absorb the forces of a rear-end collision. All five three-point seat belts feature height adjustment and pretensioners.

Although well constructed, the interior is simple and uncluttered. There is no pushing of the styling envelope inside the cabin. Everything is close at hand and easy to use. The gauges are easy to decipher as well. Seating is comfortable and engineered for fatigue-free touring. A decent-size trunk with a low lift-over also encourages cross-country excursions.

At $31,800, the S60 T5 is reasonably priced. It competes with the likes of the Audi A6 and Acura TL. Offering sensible engine choices, uncompromising safety, a fetching exterior and European-style handling, the S60 can go toe to toe with any sedan in its segment.

Other standard features not already mentioned: eight-way power front seats, tilt/telescoping steering wheel, remote keyless entry, power windows and door locks, cruise control, dual-power heated outboard mirrors, trip computer and dual-zone automatic climate control. Leather seats are a $1,300 option. The $450 Cold Weather Touring Package adds security side glass, memory mirrors and electric foldable rear headrests.

The test S60 T5 had $5,200 worth of options in all. With the $575 delivery charge, the total price came to $37,575.

Heaps, Russ
The Washington Times
March 16, 2001
